Title: An investigation of optimum safety stock level for maintenance, reliability and operation materials based on criticality of material and equipment
Source title: International Journal of Supply Chain Management
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Department, Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sudjatmiko, B., Industrial Engineering Department, Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sahroni, T.R., Industrial Engineering Department, Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper presents a study to determine a safety stock level calculation for Maintenance, Reliability and Operation (MRO) materials in oil and gas industries. The challenge to set a safety stock for MRO materials is uncertainty of demand and lead time especially in industry where the operation plant is far away from materials manufacturer. The correlation is presented between maintenance activities and inventory control strategy to provide acceptable service level through combined the equipment and material criticality with optimum inventory safety stock level by linked the acceptable downtime of equipment with lead time of ordering materials. The result shows the criticality material and equipment is increased the assurance of inventory control to set a service level and incorporated in the safety stock calculation. The contribution of this paper is to find an alternative solution by approaching the criticality of material and equipment. In addition, by using this approach the optimization for maintenance, reliability and operation materials can be determined. Furthermore, this approach also provides satisfactory for both parties, maintenance as receiver of services and inventory control as provider of services. © ExcelingTech Pub, UK.
Author Keywords: Criticality; Downtime; Lead time; MTBF; Safety stock
